executive_context: This analysis maps critical stakeholders in the grant writing AI market. Players are active market participants who buy, sell, or provide services. Influencers shape market dynamics through policy, standards, or advocacy. Acceptability ratings indicate alignment with Rayla AI's innovation.

players.name: Small-to-midsize nonprofits (<$5M budget)
players.note: Primary target struggling with 40+ hr proposals; no consultant budget; desperately need affordable AI solution with high pain point alignment

players.name: University research administration
players.note: 20-50 applications annually with compliance burden; institutional budgets support SaaS; strong enterprise tier opportunity

players.name: Early-stage impact startups (seed to Series A)
players.note: First-time grant seekers lacking expertise; tech-savvy early adopters underserved by traditional consultants

players.name: Nonprofit capacity-building orgs
players.note: Train smaller nonprofits on fundraising; natural distribution channel; mission-aligned; white-label potential

players.name: Independent grant consultants
players.note: Current partners (2 firms) but may resist if positioned as replacement vs. efficiency tool; channel or competitor depending on messaging

players.name: Private foundation program officers
players.note: Evaluate proposals and recommend tools; could become prescribers if convinced AI improves quality; authenticity concerns

players.name: Instrumentl (grant discovery)
players.note: Direct competitor at $3K-$7K/year with established position; discovery-focused but could add AI writing to compete

players.name: ChatGPT/Claude (generic AI)
players.note: Indirect competitor for DIY grant writing; free/low-cost threatens pricing but lacks grant specialization; massive distribution advantage

players.name: Traditional grant consultants
players.note: $150-$300/hour providers threatened by AI efficiency; may influence clients against adoption; relationship-based advantage

influencers.name: National Science Foundation (NSF)
influencers.note: Major federal funder with strict requirements; sets research proposal standards; unclear stance on AI content; could mandate or ban

influencers.name: National Institutes of Health (NIH)
influencers.note: Largest research funder; increased compliance scrutiny; position on AI assistance undefined; potential supporter or barrier

influencers.name: Grants.gov (federal portal)
influencers.note: Mandatory submission platform; integration essential for workflow; technical standards could enable or block AI features

influencers.name: Grant Professionals Association
influencers.note: Professional association concerned about AI displacing members; influences ethics standards; threat vs. tool positioning critical

influencers.name: Federal grant policy (OMB, White House)
influencers.note: Set oversight policies for federal grantmaking; 2025 focus on outcomes; scrutiny could favor data tools or create barriers

influencers.name: Council on Foundations
influencers.note: 900+ foundation association; advocates nonprofit capacity building; supportive of tools democratizing funding access

influencers.name: Nonprofit Technology Network (NTEN)
influencers.note: Tech adoption advocates; tech-forward practitioner community; natural amplification channel and innovation validator

influencers.name: Major philanthropic foundations
influencers.note: Gates, Ford, etc.; innovation-focused; nonprofit capacity interest; enterprise license customers; thought leadership influence

influencers.name: Tech media (TechCrunch, VentureBeat)
influencers.note: Validates market opportunity; AI vertical SaaS coverage; positive narrative around democratizing capital access
